docs.lead_paragraph: FACING a dire state economic forecast and increased security costs related to the threat of terrorism, Westchester County Executive Andrew J. Spano has proposed a budget for 2002 that would increase the property tax levy by 9.5 percent, the largest county tax increase in 12 years. If approved by the County Legislature in December, it would be the first property tax levy increase of Mr. Spano's tenure. During the previous three years, Mr. Spano, a Democrat, has reduced the property tax levy by 7.8 percent.
docs.abstract: Westchester County Executive Andrew Spano, citing expected economic slowdown and increased security costs related to threat of terrorism, proposes $1.3 billion budget for fiscal year 2002 that includes 9.5 percent property tax hike; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a suite high above the rink at the Nassau Coliseum, Tom Cox sat in a plush leather swivel chair, a satisfied smile spreading across his face. The scenario couldn't have been better. Down on the ice, the Islanders were winning 2-1 in the second period. The Knicks were on the main scoreboard's four-sided screen in the center of the arena. Mr. Cox was snacking on sushi. His loafers had just been buffed by a shoeshine man. And Dawn Stegner, a licensed massage therapist, was kneading his neck and shoulders.

headline.main: At the Coliseum, in the Lap of, Yes, Luxury

docs.abstract: Long Island Journal column: New perks at executive skyboxes during New York Islanders' games at Nassau Coliseum include sushi snacks, shoeshines, massages, manicures, makeovers and personal shoppers; artists affiliated with Heather Buggee's nonprofit Splashes of Hope paint cheerful scenes in hospital cancer units and health care facilities; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR years, life insurance was a hard sell. Even some companies that sold it began dropping ''life insurance'' from their names and calling themselves financial services companies. They recognized that Americans had become less interested in buying protection for their families than in making investments intended to make themselves comfortable in retirement. But the terrorist attacks turned life insurance into a hot commodity.

headline.main: Personal Business; Shaken Consumers Are Looking to Life Insurance

docs.abstract: Terrorist attacks on US cause shaken consumers to look to life insurance, making it easier for agents and companies to sell; rates have not increased; photo; list of Web sites providing information (M)
docs.snippet: FOR years, life insurance was a hard sell. Even some companies that sold it began dropping ''life insurance'' from their names and calling themselves financial services companies. They recognized that Americans had become less interested in buying...

docs.lead_paragraph: Amid a growing sense of desperation about the finances of hospitals in New York City, the state's political leaders, hospital chiefs and leaders of the powerful hospital workers' union met yesterday and agreed to step up the pressure on Congress and the White House for increased federal aid. The Republican leaders of the House and aides to President Bush have said they do not want to use a coming round of appropriations bills to add to the roughly $10 billion in aid already approved for New York's recovery from the destruction of the World Trade Center. But the hospital workers' group, 1199/S.E.I.U., New York's Health and Human Service Union, and hospital leaders signaled that they were, if anything, raising their sights, seeking more than $1 billion and looking for new ways to couch that request.

headline.main: Clamor Grows For Fiscal Aid To Hospitals

docs.abstract: New York's elected officials in Washington and Albany meet with Dennis Rivera and others from 1199/SEIU, New York's Health and Human Service Union, to discuss urgent need for financial aid to city's hospitals; union says it is seeking more than $1 billion to help hardest-hit facilities and that Sept 11 attack cost more than $350 million in readiness, security and supplies; Rep Charles Rangel is pessimistic about chances of getting federal aid, but Sen Charles Schumer is more hopeful (M)
docs.snippet: Amid a growing sense of desperation about the finances of hospitals in New York City, the state's political leaders, hospital chiefs and leaders of the powerful hospital workers' union met yesterday and agreed to step up the pressure on Congress and...

docs.lead_paragraph: A new round in the national debate over prescription drugs opened today with a study from researchers at Tufts University estimating that the average cost of developing a new drug has more than doubled since 1987, to $802 million. Dr. Kenneth I. Kaitin, director of the Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development, which issued the report, said, ''Bringing new drugs to market has always been an expensive, high-risk proposition, and our latest analysis indicates that costs have continued to skyrocket.''

headline.main: Research Cost For New Drugs Said to Soar

docs.abstract: Study from researchers at Tufts University estimates that average cost of developing new drug has more than doubled since 1987, to $802 million; Drs Kenneth I Kaitin, director of Tufts Center for Study of Drug Development, and Joseph A DiMasi, principal author of study, comment; researchers say it cost average of $231 million to develop new drug in 1987; say if cost had risen at pace of inflation, it would have reached $318 million in 2000; Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association welcomes study; some consumer advocates criticize study as biased and say it overstataes costs of drug development; Sen Ron Wyden says study drives home need for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs; Repr Henry A Waxman says pharmaceutical costs, including research, are hidden from view (M)
